name: electricity production, hydro, pumped storage | electricity, high voltage | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/16806/documentation

This dataset represents the production of high voltage electricity in a pumped storage power plant unit in India - Maharashtra (a state/union territory in India) in 2012. The calculation of this dataset is based on data of reservoir hydro power plant units. For this, a representative sample of various types of dams in Switzerland is taken into account, i.e. 52 reservoir power plants with an annual gross production output of 17.8 TWh  and an installed capacity of 9130 MW.  Reservoir power plants and pumped storage power plants are dealt with together due to the fact that the construction efforts are related. Lifetime is assumed to be 150 years for the dam and 80 years for the rest of materials. The data refers to plant operation of a mix of types of dams built between 1945 and 1970; therefore they might not be representative for more modern construction, for an individual type and for small-scale and smallest-scale plants. This dataset is created as a child of the global dataset. All values except the annaul production volume are directly inherited from the global dataset. The annual production volume value is taken from India- specific source.;[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:; - electricity production, hydro, pumped storage, IN, 1945 - 2015 (39fdee6b-2149-4cf2-80cf-cd194a1ade9b)]

From water pumped up from a lower to an upper reservoir.

The activity ends with 1 kWh of high voltage electricity produced at the power plant and arrived at the busbar.

The dataset includes the use of pump energy (electricity, high voltage), lubricant oil, the volume of the reservoir, the mass of water passing through the turbines and an estimation of greenhouse gas emissions out of the water reservoir. 

The dataset doesn"t include an analysis of net greenhouse gas emissions (due to a lack of respective information) and the hydrological and biological impacts are only rudimentary included via land use (occupation and transformation) data.
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The Annual Production Volume is for the time period of 01.04.2012 - 31.03.2013. Central Electricity Authority (CEA), India documents annual electricity production data for the mentioned time period.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data represent the average of a characteristic sample of Swiss reservoir hydropower plants, valid for pumped storage hydro power plants.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Definition of pumped storage in this dataset: The water is not being pumped for circulation reasons, but for increasing the inflow of a reservoir. Net production is the gross production minus about 1% losses. Additionally there is energy needed for pumping. The efficiency of a pumped storage hydropower plant is around 70% (p.14 in Bauer et al. 2007).
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset has been extrapolated from an original dataset covering the geography CH (Switzerland), which in its turn is extrapolated from a dataset for electricity production in a reservoir plant without pumping. The uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly. Only the annual production volume and the power plant own use values are extracted from the India-specific source. CEA. (2014). CO2 Baseline Database for the Indian Power Sector. User Guide, Ministry of Power, Government of India, New Delhi. Retrieved 12 04, 2016, from http://cea.nic.in/reports/others/thermal/tpece/cdm_co2/user_guide_ver10.pdf
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: The inventory is generated using statistical data, literature data and modelling.

exchanges.description: Estimation. This dataset is based on data of Swiss reservoir power plants. Due to the fact that pumped storage power plants do not produce hydro-electricity, the amount of electricity provided is assigned to a separate module. The creation of such a module was not possible, because no differentiation between reservoir and pumped storage power plant was made in the considered power plant sample. Separating the expenditures for the construction of the power plant is neither possible nor reasonable; therefore the same infrastructure module is used as for the construction of a reservoir power plant. As reference factor the net energy production of the reservoir power plant is used.

flow.name: electricity, high voltage
flow.category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution

exchanges.description:
Standard values for landuse are assumed.
The original state before setting up the reservoir has to be classified as module "transformation, from unspecified" due to the fact that various types of flooded ground can be distinguished. The flooded area partly consisted of alpine meadows and grazing land, rarely also villages had to be resettled; often impassable, rocky alpine valleys and gorges were filled with water, where only marginal vegetation and no agricultural use was possible. The definition of the character and the environmental value (e.g. forest, areas with rare mushrooms, moorlands, etc.) of the affected areas were not possible, due to the lack of information.
Literature value/calculated value. This exchange amount is taken over from datasets for both alpine (2.3E-5) and non-alpine (2.3E-4) reservoirs. For the global dataset, the amount is calculated as weighted average of pumped storage plants alpine/non-alpine type. Regarding reservoir power stations, land (i.e. meadows, moorlands, gravel areas etc.) is mainly occupied by reservoirs. Averaged over the investigated sample and distributed over life time the specific land use amounts to 0.0035 m2a/kWh; the transformation of land amounts to 0.000023 m2/kWh (alpine reservoirs). These values are multiplied by a factor 10 for non-alpine reservoirs..

Calculated value. This exchange has been taken from a dataset for a Swiss alpine reservoir power plant without pumping. Total emissions of greenhouse gases are assumed to be 0.3 CO2equivalents per kWh. Dinitrogen monoxide emissions (N2O) emerge from nitrification and denitrification processes. Based on measurements of Swiss natural lakes, gross dinitrogen monoxide emissions amount to 8-16 umol per m2 and per day. Because of the limited nitrification and denitrification processes at reservoirs in Switzerland, a maximum value of N2O-emissions ranging from 0.24 to 2.4 umol/m2 can be estimated. As a result N2O-emissions between 1.4.10^-5 and 1.4.10^-4 g N2/kWh, respectively 0.004 - 0.04 g CO2-equivalent/kWh with an average value of 7.7.10^-5 g/kWh of N2O are calculated.

exchanges.description: Literature value/calculated value. The needed amount of infrastructure per kWh produced is calculated with the lifetime and the annual net energy production (16500GWh/a). The global value represents a weighted average of alpine and non-alpine reservoir pumped storage plants.

Regarding reservoir power stations, land (i.e. meadows, moorlands, gravel areas etc.) is mainly occupied by reservoirs. Averaged over the investigated sample and distributed over life time the specific land use amounts to 0.0035 m2a/kWh; the transformation of land amounts to 0.000023 m2/kWh (alpine reservoirs). Estimation. This dataset is based on data of Swiss reservoir power plants. The lubricating oil is in a closed loop system (i.e. cannot get into the turbined water system) and is disposed annualy as waste oil in a hazardous waste treatment plant. The information given is based on own assumptions.

exchanges.description: Estimation. This exchange has been taken over from a dataset for a Swiss reservoir power plant without pumping. For the consumption of lubricating oil during plant operation no data was available. It is assumed that both turbines and run-of-river plants need the same amount of oil hence the information about lubricating oil consumption of run-of-rivers is adopted. A consumption of lubricating oil for turbines of 9 liters per GWh is estimated. With an oil density of 0.84 kg/l this amounts to 0.007 g/kWh. The lubricating oil is in a closed loop system (i.e. cannot get into the turbined water system) and is disposed annualy as waste oil in a hazardous waste treatment plant.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. This exchange has been taken over from a dataset for a Swiss reservoir power plant without pumping. The usable capacity of reservoirs is an important figure both for significant water supply regions and for the definition of ecological relevant indices. First of all the usable capacity is a measurement for the rearrangement of the runoff regime over time, i.e. the amount of water detracted temporarily from the natural water cycle and returned to the surface waters with delay. Depending on the type of reservoir (daily, monthly, annual reservoir) the delay takes less or more time. Second, the usable capacity of reservoirs is a measurement for the occupied volume of reservoirs. Thereby, the volume of the fluctuation area is considered, i.e. not the total reservoir volume.

Hertwich, E.G. 2013. Addressing Biogenic Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Hydropower in LCA. Environmental Sciency&Technology, 47, 9604-9611
Literature value/calculated  value. Hertwich 2013 provides an analysis of greenhouse gas emissions from hydropower plants. 89 data points are available for temperate non-alpine plants, from which the average CO2 and CH4 emissions are calculated. Only 10 data points are available for temperate alpine plants which seem not to be representative, so that the greenhouse gas emissions from version 3.1 are kept. The value in the global dataset for pumped hydrpower is calculated as production volume weighted average of alpine and non-alpine type pumped storage plants.

flow.name: Methane, non-fossil
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Calculated value. This exchange has been taken over from a dataset for a Swiss alpine reservoir power plant without pumping for the alpine type pumped storage plants. For non-alpine type plants, the amount is multiplied by a factor 10. The amount of turbined water equates to the used water amount (i.e. the water amount detracted from the river) less small losses like the evaporation of reservoirs. With respect to the ecological importance the following has to be considered: the turbined amount of water is via physical laws related to the produced amount of electricity, i.e. the turbined amount of water does not provide independent, ecological relevant information. The specific turbined amount of water (in m3/kWh) represents a value that is inversely proportional to the average net head. However, the turbined amount of water is an ecological relevant measurement in terms of representing the water amount that is in parts detracted from the natural water cycle. Based on the Swiss sample the specific turbined water amount accounts for 0.81 m3/kWh.

flow.name: Water, turbine use, unspecified natural origin

Regarding reservoir power stations, land (i.e. meadows, moorlands, gravel areas etc.) is mainly occupied by reservoirs. Averaged over the investigated sample and distributed over life time the specific land use amounts to 0.0035 m2a/kWh; the transformation of land amounts to 0.000023 m2/kWh (alpine reservoirs). Estimation. The electricity source for pumping is not known. Hence the  electricity mix of this geography is assumed to be used as pump electricity.
